Sanders Shares Love for Bills
While he may still be undecided regarding his playing future, Sanders made it clear that he holds a lot of love for Buffalo.

For me, hold myself to a standard in which I want to produce and which I want to give a team.”
Sanders came to the Bills last offseason on a one-year contract and became a reliable target for quarterback Josh Allen.
He spoke highly of Allen, saying he is high on the list of quarterbacks he’s played with during his career — a strong list that includes Drew Brees, Peyton Manning and Ben Roethlisberger.
The Pro Bowl receiver said it was hard for him to decide, saying he only wanted to play another year if his heart was fully in it and otherwise hinting that he’s ready to retire.
He made 42 receptions for 626 yards and four touchdowns, and scored his first-career playoff touchdown in a 47-17 win over the New England Patriots in the Wild Card round.
The 35-year-old receiver hinted during the last season that it could be his last in the league, and it appears he is still mulling over what to do next.
Sanders had hinted about retirement during the 2021 season, saying his goal was to win one more Super Bowl before calling it a career.
“I played with so many great quarterbacks, and this guy right here, he always pops up in the front of my mind,” Sanders said.
The Bills also brought back some of their free-agent receivers from last season, re-signing Isaiah McKenzie and Jake Kumerow.
The veteran wide receiver spoke this week about his past season with the Buffalo Bills and his uncertain future in the NFL.
